Here, UCR professor of political science and public policy Kevin Esterling weighs in on Musk's pending acquisition. Esterling is director of the Laboratory for Technology, Communication and Democracy.

description: Set in the Inland Empire, her tenth novel, weaves together people, history, and scenery.

title: Can Putin accept peace but also save face?
description: Wednesday, we asked UC Riverside Professor and leading Ukraine-Russia expert Paul D'Anieri to weigh in on breaking developments related to a 15-point peace plan being discussed that could end the month-long war between Ukraine and Russia. The conditions would surround Ukrainian neutrality — with a peace plan's fate dependent on what that means to Ukraine, Russia, and even the West.

title: Boyle Heights: Cemented in history
description: Capturing the essence of a place requires more than time. It requires confianza. Trust.    That’s why for more than a year a team co-led by a UC Riverside cultural and urban historian interviewed, researched, and documented the lives of Boyle Heights residents — all in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. For centuries, Boyle Heights, a community three miles east of downtown Los Angeles, has been home to generations of immigrants and social justice movements.

title: UC Riverside program for high school students aims to diversify STEM workforce
description: Underrepresented students will participate in carefully designed summer research and educational activities at UC Riverside

title: China-Russia: Any alliance is conditional, temporary
description: Related to Russia's ongoing war with Ukraine, China is fielding as many requests for aid from Russia as it's receiving threats from the West about what will happen if it provides that aid. We asked two UC Riverside China experts to provide perspective about the likelihood of all-in Chinese aid to Russia.

title: Fruit fungus for the win at Grad Slam

description: Experts on the plight of the unhoused contend the plan would criminalize being poor and mentally ill

title: New book by Allison Adelle Hedge Coke, ‘Look at This Blue,’ is a tough love letter to California
description: Poetry collection captures the author's own life, as well as many of the golden state’s overlooked truths: genocide, environmental degradation, and climate change.

description: To gauge the impacts of dark mornings in some parts of the country, we spoke with two UC Riverside experts

title: Why doesn’t fire kill some bacteria and fungi?
description: UC Riverside scientists will spend the next three years studying the traits that allow soil microbes to respond to fire, as well as the role those microbes play in storing or emitting powerful greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide or nitrous oxide.

description: SAVE focuses on mutations in SARS-CoV-2 and emerging virus variants

description: UCR research shows race evasiveness harms teacher educators and charts a path toward identifying and disrupting racism

description: A new tool designed by UC Riverside researchers can better assess an overlooked indicator of global warming: the variety of bugs, worms, and snails living in high mountain streams.

title: Smoking reduces wealth’s tendency to increase life expectancy
description: Smoking dominates other factors, including amount of wealth, in shortening lifespan

description: Inland Empire families don’t have to wade through school and service systems alone

title: UC Riverside hunts for COVID-19 variants in California
description: Genetic analysis of COVID-19 samples at UC Riverside is helping state officials prepare for potential infection surges caused by new variants of the disease.

description: Labor shortages will be region’s key restraint on economic growth

title: Gay migration happens but not always to gay-friendly places, reports new study
description: Study also shows that straight people prefer to live in places that match their attitudes toward sexuality

title: Why Venus rotates, slowly, despite sun’s powerful grip
description: If not for the soupy, fast-moving atmosphere on Venus, Earth’s sister planet would likely not rotate. Instead, Venus would be locked in place, always facing the sun the way the same side of the moon always faces Earth.

title: $1 million award supports first generation students
description: UC Riverside has been selected as one of 10 American Talent Initiative members to participate in the Kessler Scholars Collaborative. As part of the collaborative, UCR will receive a five-year, $1 million grant. First established at the University of Michigan in 2008, Kessler Scholars provides student financial support and academic, professional, and personal support services to first-generation, limited-income students throughout their four-year college experiences.

title: California’s creative economy bounces back but expands unevenly
description: New analysis tracks performance of state’s creative industries before, during, and after covid, revealing longer term direction

title: UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: This year’s Los Angeles Times Festival of Books includes a UC Riverside star-studded lineup.  Nineteen UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be participating in this annual literary event that takes place at the University of Southern California. More than 550 authors, poets, artists, chefs, celebrities, and musicians will gather on April 23-24. See full details: LA Times Festival of Books.

title: To mask, or not to mask?
description: To gauge whether scientists agree with popular sentiment around mask wearing, we check in here with three UC Riverside virologists and epidemiologists.

title: What is your moral responsibility in Ukraine?
description: Letters to the editor populate the pages of media outlets, speaking to America's and Americans' moral authority to act, or not to act, in Ukraine. You and I didn't cause this. Then why do we feel we should be doing something more - and what do we do with that anxiety? We turned to John Martin Fischer, a UC Riverside philosophy professor who is a world-leading expert on free will and moral responsibility. Fischer's ruminations on near-death experiences have been consumed by millions in his writings and on YouTube videos.

title: Amir Zaki publishes 23 years of photography in new monograph, ‘Building+Becoming’
description: The book weaves stories that capture both nature and architecture. It goes on sale on April 26

title: With dwindling water supplies, the timing of rainfall matters
description: A new UC Riverside study shows it’s not how much extra water you give your plants, but when you give it that counts.

title: Meet the forest microbes that can survive megafires
description: New UC Riverside research shows fungi and bacteria able to survive redwood tanoak forest megafires are microbial “cousins” that often increase in abundance after feeling the flames.

title: A project about Zoom... Zoom... Zoom, on Zoom
description: A pair of short films were a hit at the April 13 “Filmworks – Original Short Films” held at the University Theatre, drawing attention to a suite of pandemic monologues and songs professor Bella Merlin created along with students, entitled “20:20 Vision.” For the first time this week, the short film/music video “Zoom,” and other components of 20:20 Vision are publicly available on YouTube.

title: UCR among top 1.3% of world institutions
description: UC Riverside ranked in the top 1.3% of universities worldwide in the 2022-23 Center for World University Rankings, released Monday, April 25. The campus ranked No. 249 out of 19,788 institutions. Nationally, UCR landed at No. 81. The rankings are published by the Center for World University Rankings, a consultancy based in the United Arab Emirates. Institutions are evaluated on four key factors: education, employability, faculty, and research.

title: How genome organization influences cell fate
description: UC Riverside-led study identifies how blood stem cells maintain their fate

title: Discovery about coral-algal symbiosis could help coral reefs recover after bleaching events
description: Algae’s ability to establish symbiosis in coral without photosynthesis could help fight coral bleaching

title: Lesser known ozone layer’s outsized role in planet warming
description: New UC Riverside-led research has identified a lesser-known form of ozone playing a big role in heating the Southern Ocean — one of Earth’s main cooling systems.

title: New method detects deepfake videos with up to 99% accuracy
description: Two-pronged technique detects manipulated facial expressions and identity swaps

title: How drones can help dairy farms manage methane emissions
description: Accurate atmospheric measurements directly over their farm can help farmers fight climate change

title: Art Riggs remembered for pioneering research on diabetes, arthritis and cancer
description: UC Riverside alumnus and friend Arthur D. (Art) Riggs, a pioneering researcher and expert in diabetes who helped launch the biotechnology industry, died March 23, 2022. He was 82.

title: Candy-coated pills could prevent pharmaceutical fraud
description: Colorful nonpareils can uniquely identify drug capsules and counterfeit fashions

title: Insights from algae genes unlock mysteries of plant growth and health
description: The discovery will improve biofuel production from algae and help develop heat-tolerant crops.

title: UCR ecologists work toward post-fire rebirth of healthy landscapes
description: The worst fire impacts this year are predicted to hit Northern California’s higher elevation forests and Southern California’s chaparral-clad mountainous National Forest lands. To aid recovery, UC Riverside ecologists are collaborating with the US Forest Service to target these spots with new post-fire ecological restoration strategies.

title: Is there still a benefit to masking?
description: UC Riverside epidemiologist weighs in on how protective your mask is when nobody around you is masked

title: New technology offers fighting chance against grapevine killer
description: Scientists at UC Riverside have a shot at eradicating a deadly threat to vineyards posed by the glassy-winged sharpshooter, just as its resistance to insecticide has been growing.

title: In search of UC Riverside's missing not-mascot
description: He is a UC Riverside icon, beloved even, and yet discouraged from attending official university events. Before his refresh, at least, he had the appearance of having been through it. Sun-bleached, sort of grubby, like he was on the losing side of a fight at the juice bar.

title: Remembering ‘isotope queen’ Marilyn Fogel, pioneering scientist, beloved mentor
description: Marilyn Fogel, endowed geoecology professor at UC Riverside, died on May 11 in Mariposa, Calif. She was 69. She pioneered the use of isotopes to understand the life history of organisms, both modern and ancient. In so doing, she helped develop biogeochemistry as a new field of science and earned the moniker ‘isotope queen.’

title: ‘Forbidden City’ shines light on Mao Zedong’s dancing girls
description: Vanessa Hua’s latest novel "Forbidden City" explores the little-known history and influence of the teenage revolutionaries in Chairman Mao’s inner circle

title: Different parental messages about race and ethnicity have different effects on teens’ drug use
description: Study finds promoting appreciation of ethnic-racial heritage has the potential to bolster youth’s internal resources against substance use

title: NEH grant helps research Pueblo, Colorado’s music history
description: Xóchitl C. Chávez, assistant professor of music at UCR, is a co-principal investigator.

title: ‘The Anxiety of Laughing’ will be screened at Dances With Films festival in June
description: The film was directed by UCR Professor Robin Uriel Russin and written by UCR alum Andrew Justvig.

title: Fundraising head at HBCU Morehouse to lead Advancement
description: UC Riverside has named Monique Michelle Dozier as its vice chancellor for University Advancement. Dozier is currently vice president for Advancement and chief advancement officer at Morehouse College in Atlanta, which is the nation’s only historically Black liberal arts college dedicated to educating and developing men of color, specifically Black men. She will begin her new role at UCR on Aug. 1 overseeing University Advancement, which includes Development, Alumni Engagement, Advancement Finance and Administration, and University Communications.

title: Money magazine ranks UCR No. 40 among 623 colleges
description: UC Riverside was ranked No. 40 on Money magazine’s latest “Best Values” college ranking, released May 16.  It represents an increase of eight places over Money's last best value list, on which UCR ranked No. 48. Among public universities, UCR ranked No. 31 on the list, up from No. 32.

title: Student Freedom Initiative adds UCR to its next cohort of member institutions
description: Today, Student Freedom Initiative announced the next round of Minority Serving Institutions, or MSIs, that will participate in its program.  UC Riverside, ranked No. 1 in the U.S. for social mobility by U.S. News and World Report, was one of the universities selected.

title: Girly and a fighter. But are MMA women breaking barriers?
description: Study finds male-dominated MMA is not friendly to gender equality.

title: Expert: Student loan forgiveness is a win - but only for some
description: On Wednesday, President Joe Biden announced a student loan debt program that would forgive $10,000 in debt for borrowers who earn less than $125,000 and an additional $10,000 for those who received Pell Grants. Many borrowers are celebrating the liberation from debt that — for some — has prevented them from buying homes and setting aside savings.

title: Magazine ranks UCR No. 4 for Pell Grant performance
description: Washington Monthly magazine has ranked UC Riverside No. 4 among 444 universities nationwide in terms of its Pell Grant student performance. The accolade, released Monday as part of Washington Monthly’s 2022 college rankings, represents UCR’s excellence in several Pell performance categories that were factored. Those include:

title: Family secret inspires new novel by UC Riverside’s Kate Anger
description: A story about coming-of-age, betrayal, and revenge, ‘The Shinnery’ is inspired by the author’s family history and a trial that shook 1890s Texas.

title: A shot in the arm
description: UC Riverside experts answer questions on Americans needing just one COVID-19 booster vaccine each year

title: 'The Most Important World Leader Since World War II'
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is the man whose actions inserted the terms perestroika and glasnost into the international vernacular. In 1985, Mikhail Gorbachev became the leader of the Soviet Union, presiding over a remarkable five-year span during which until-then unimaginable democratic reforms were instituted,  the Berlin Wall fell, communism was virtually wiped from Eastern Europe, and the Soviet Republic crumbled.

title: Forbes magazine ranks UC Riverside No. 33 public university
description: UC Riverside is the No. 33 public university in a college ranking from Forbes magazine. UCR was among several UC campuses and 17 public universities in the top 50. The methodology for the Forbes list relies on data from two federal databases, the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, or IPEDS, and the College Scorecard, as well as several databases that gauge graduates’ earning.

title: The scent that could save California’s avocados
description: UC Riverside scientists are on the hunt for a chemical that disrupts “evil” weevils’ mating and could prevent them from destroying California’s supply of avocados.

title: UCR, Inland Empire receive $18 million grant
description: UC Riverside and the Inland Empire have received $18 million from a statewide investment of $250 million that will establish K-16 Education Collaboratives to address equity gaps and improve education-to-career pipelines in each region of the state.

title: Researchers devise tunable conducting edge
description: Technology reported in UC Riverside-led study has nanoelectronic applications

title: Latinos, British post-punk music, and growing up in Southern California
description: New book by UC Riverside’s Richard Rodríguez offers personal stories as he explores musical connections between Latino fans and British bands.

title: U.S. News names UCR No. 1 public for social mobility
description: UC Riverside is the top public university in the U.S. for social mobility, according to the just-released 2022-23 U.S. News & World Report college rankings.

title: The queen is dead. Will the monarchy survive? Should it?
description: Sept. 8, Queen Elizabeth II died at 96 after a 70-year reign, the longest of any British monarch in history. We asked a UC Riverside British history expert, Jonathan Eacott, and a British-born UCR political scientist, Shaun Bowler, to assess the future of the monarchy.

title: Unraveling a mystery surrounding cosmic matter
description: UC Riverside physicist and colleague invoke the cosmological collider to explain why matter, and not antimatter, dominates the universe

title: Back to School: UCR Welcome Week 2022
description: All UCR Highlanders are invited to celebrate the start of our 2022-23 academic year with a bunch of fun and informative events hosted by various campus partners. This is a great time to discover new departments, reconnect with familiar programs, and add friends to your list of followers and followees.  As thanks to students who are joining the fun, University Communications is hosting a giveaway!

title: Could more of Earth’s surface host life?
description: Of all known planets, Earth is as friendly to life as any planet could possibly be — or is it? If Jupiter’s orbit changes, a new study shows Earth could be more hospitable than it is today.

title: Why are dark matter halos of ultra-diffuse galaxies so … odd?
description: A UC Riverside physicist explains

description: UC Riverside scientists have a new chemical weapon to seduce and kill the invasive, long-nosed beetles destroying California palm trees by the tens of thousands.

title: Marginalized communities of color face high COVID-19 risk
description: UC Riverside study focused on farm-working communities in California’s Eastern Coachella Valley

title: PFAS chemicals do not last forever
description: The use of sulfite and iodide under ultraviolet light can destroy PFAS in water in a few hours

title: A drunk driver killed her parents. Now she’s graduating to honor them
description: Azalea Corral has a family photo that shows her three younger siblings and parents smiling together against a Santa Barbara countryside backdrop. It was taken on February 8, 2020 — the last time they would pose together for a photo.  The following day, both her parents succumbed to bodily injuries after a drunk driver struck them while they were out on their usual evening stroll in Goleta, a community about 12 miles west of Santa Barbara. Corral’s siblings were in the house; she was on a train back to Riverside.

title: UCR spotlighted in discussion of mental health on campus
description: The widely circulated publication Inside Higher Ed published a story this past week that features a "virtual roundtable" at UC Riverside with the secretary of the U.S. Department of Education.

title: Highlander Pep Band surprises campus with hype song
description: Imagine you’re sitting in class on a random Thursday morning, listening to your chemistry professor, and then a 15-piece band bursts in the room blasting the Macklemore and Ryan Lewis throwback hit, “Can’t Hold Us” — but the tuba, symbols, trumpet, and flute version. If you were on campus on May 18, you didn’t have to imagine it because it happened in real life — and the UC Riverside Highlander Pep Band filled random locations around campus with music while a camera crew filmed crowd reactions.

title: No more flu for you? Discovery blocks influenza virus’ replication in cells
description: SUMOylation inhibitor could lead to highly effective ways to treat the flu and other respiratory viruses

title: Antibiotics wreak havoc on athletic performance
description: By killing essential gut bacteria, antibiotics ravage athletes’ motivation and endurance. The UC Riverside-led mouse study suggests the microbiome is a big factor separating athletes from couch potatoes.

description: Under anaerobic conditions, common microbial communities can break the ultra-strong carbon-fluorine bond

description: UniHealth Foundation grant to UC Riverside aims to increase the health and well-being of the unhoused population in Riverside County

description: Talking about innovation can hurt a firm’s market performance but enhance earnings

title: Human skin can be damaged by exposure to thirdhand smoke and electronic cigarette spills
description: A relatively short exposure is sufficient to cause the damage, UC Riverside study finds

title: You, too, can grow California’s oldest living orange variety
description: The 1000th tree okayed for growing by California’s Citrus Clonal Protection Program happens to be the oldest living orange variety in the state.

title: New strategies to save the world’s most indispensable grain
description: A UC Riverside-led team has learned what happens to the roots of rice plants when they’re confronted with two types of stressful scenarios: too much water, or too little. These observations form the basis of new protective strategies.

title: Genetic discovery could spell mosquitoes’ death knell
description: A UC Riverside genetic discovery could turn disease-carrying mosquitoes into insect Peter Pans, preventing them from ever maturing or multiplying.

title: Scientists fail to locate once-common CA bumble bees
description: Several species of California bumble bees have gone missing in the first statewide census of the fuzzy pollinators in 40 years. If they can be found, a recent court ruling could help save them.

title: Protecting computer vision from adversarial attacks
description: UC Riverside engineers are developing methods to keep self-driving cars and autonomous drones from being hacked

title: Why Jupiter doesn’t have rings like Saturn
description: Because it’s bigger, Jupiter ought to have larger, more spectacular rings than Saturn has. But new UC Riverside research shows Jupiter’s massive moons prevent that vision from lighting up the night sky.

title: Gun control legislation is popular; why won't it pass?
description: The routine has been too familiar for too many years. A school shooting or mass shooting event occurs and stirs the American consciousness for a moment. But a week or two passes and talk of gun-control legislation fades. The issue goes into hibernation until the next mass shooting event. In 2018, an opinion article by UCR political science Professor Ben Bishin was published in The Washington Post. It was Bishin's attempt to explain why the cycle keeps repeating itself, and who's to blame.

title: Regents approve plans for new School of Business building
description: The Regents of the University of California have approved construction plans for a new UC Riverside School of Business building that will provide more instructional and administrative space to meet growing enrollment demand. The vote, which took place July 20, allows the campus to move forward with construction this fall. The new building is expected to be completed by fall 2024.

title: New dean of School of Education named
description: Joi Spencer has been named the dean of UC Riverside’s School of Education, effective Jan. 1, 2023.  Spencer is a professor of Mathematics Education at the University of San Diego, in the School of Leadership and Education Sciences, or SOLES. During 16 years at USD, Spencer has been associate dean and, most recently, interim dean of SOLES.

title: UC Riverside tests a reading comprehension intervention for students in the middle grades with autism spectrum disorder
description: The study will implement an evidence-based reading intervention program in Southern California and Central Texas

title: UC Riverside part of new Hispanic universities alliance
description: UC Riverside is among 20 of the nation’s top research universities that have formed the Alliance of Hispanic Serving Research Universities. The announcement was made June 9 in Washington, D.C. The 20 universities represent every university that has been both categorized as R1 (very high research activity) by the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education and designated as a Hispanic Serving Institution by the U.S. Department of Education.

title: Coolants in Puff electronic cigarettes present health hazard
description: UC Riverside-led study highlights need for regulation to protect public health

title: Demographic dilemma: slowing population growth, not pandemic, at the root of U.S. worker shortage
description: Supply chain struggles have been widely blamed for the inability to meet consumer and business demand throughout the pandemic.

title: UCR has money to help students re-enroll
description: More than $188,000 in HEERF funds are available for students who stopped coming to UCR during the 2020-21 school year for COVID-19 related reasons.

title: Drought increases microbe-laden dust landing in Sierras
description: Dust from all over the world is landing in the Sierra Nevada mountains carrying microbes that are toxic to both plants and humans. Research from UC Riverside shows higher concentrations of the dust are landing at lower elevations, where people are more likely to be hiking.

title: Monkeypox explained
description: UC Riverside experts discuss disease symptoms, vaccines, and anxiety management

title: UC Riverside admits most California freshmen among UCs
description: UC Riverside has admitted a record number of freshmen for fall 2022 with a total of 37,262 admits — an increase of 2,591 students from the previous year, according to data released August 10 by the University of California.

title: The chemical controlling life and death in hair follicles
description: A single chemical is key to controlling when hair follicle cells divide, and when they die. This discovery could not only treat baldness, but ultimately speed wound healing because follicles are a source of stem cells.

title: New program aims to increase Latinx students conducting environmental research
description: A $342,000 grant has allowed the expansion of a UC Berkeley program to UCR.

title: Study examines ‘black boxing’ in breast cancer survivorship care
description: UC Riverside researcher argues important post-treatment information is concealed

title: UC Riverside and UC Davis help create program targeted for students who didn’t finish college
description: More than $4.85 million in state funds will allow these campuses to reengage with former UC students and California residents with some college and no degree attainment.

title: What guides our attention to faces in videos changes with age
description: UC Riverside study has implications for children’s television and autism spectrum disorder

title: Cousin of crop-killing bacteria mutating rapidly
description: A bacterial species closely related to deadly citrus greening disease is rapidly evolving its ability to infect insect hosts, and possibly plants as well.

title: The newest California water-worry is the megastorm
description: Research from UCLA and other sources recently predicted another “big one” to hit the West Coast. This time, it’s not an earthquake, but a “megastorm.” Such a flood typically hits California every 100 to 200 years, but the dynamics and frequency of this storm will be exacerbated by climate change. That is, warmer temperatures mean much of the precipitation will fall as rain, and not snow.

title: Would you get bored of eternal life?
description: John Martin Fischer’s videotaped lectures on near-death experiences and immortality have garnered the most views of any content on UCR’s YouTube site.

title: COVID-19 vaccines for very young children
description: UC Riverside vaccine expert David Lo shares his thoughts in a Q&A

title: Sleeping giant could end deep ocean life
description: A previously overlooked factor — the position of continents — helps fill Earth’s oceans with life-supporting oxygen. Continental movement could ultimately have the opposite effect, killing most deep ocean creatures.

title: Plant stress transformed into rapid tests for dangerous chemicals
description: UC Riverside scientists have modified proteins involved in plants’ natural response to stress, making them the basis of innovative tests for banned pesticides and deadly, synthetic cannabinoids.

title: Who benefits from brain training and why?
description: Joint UC Riverside and UC Irvine study shows “near transfer” predicts “far transfer”

title: ‘I am the product of rape. Here’s why I support abortion rights’
description: Victoria Reyes, an assistant professor of gender and sexuality studies at UCR, speaks from personal experience in this Q&A.

title: Ancient microbes may help us find extraterrestrial life forms
description: Using light-capturing proteins in living microbes, UC Riverside scientists helped reconstruct what life was like for some of Earth’s earliest organisms. These efforts could help us one day recognize signs of life on other planets.

title: California does not need to choose between post-pandemic economic growth and reducing carbon emissions
description: Surprisingly, environmental leader California has a smaller ‘green economy’ than the average U.S. state and would need to add many thousands of environmentally friendly jobs to catch up. The good news is it’s on track to do just that, according to a new analysis released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

title: New pathway facilitates community college students joining UC Riverside medical school
description: The School of Medicine at the University of California, Riverside, has received a grant of $1.87 million to establish the Inland Empire Regional Hub for Healthcare Opportunity, or IE RHHO, which will create a pre-med pathway for local community college students.

title: Artificial photosynthesis can produce food without sunshine
description: Scientists are developing artificial photosynthesis to help make food production more energy-efficient here on Earth, and one day possibly on Mars

title: Fewer than one-third of Inland Empire households can afford to buy a home in one of Southern California’s ‘most affordable’ housing markets
description: Despite recessionary fears, IE labor market continues to show strength

title: New report highlights key findings on the health, mental health, and social service needs of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in California
description: Data from the California Health Interview Survey and the American Community Survey highlight diversity and needs of California’s fastest growing population groups.

title: Inland Empire business activity still going strong
description: Business activity in the Inland Empire has continued to grow, and in the context of today’s increasingly uncertain economic environment, stands in stark contrast to growth trends in the nation, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The region’s economy officially transitioned from recovery to expansion in the fourth quarter of 2021 and growth is forecast to continue throughout 2022.

title: Creating dance opportunities and careers for Inland Empire youth
description: Inaugural “Celebrating our Constellation: UCR + RCC + AB Miller” event brought together UCR, Riverside City College, and AB Miller High School students.

title: Expert: NATO has a workaround to naval blockade
description: NATO member countries have walked a line in the months since Russia invaded Ukraine: Supporting Ukraine short of triggering large-scale war with Russia. That line may soon become more difficult to navigate, with Russia now threatening a member of NATO. We asked UCR political scientist and NATO expert Kelechi Kalu to assess Russia's current calculus in Ukraine.

title: NSF-funded project aims to enhance STEM graduate training in sustainable transportation
description: New UC Riverside program will train doctoral students on translating science into public policy

title: UCR professor is historical consultant to Jason Momoa’s new film ‘The Last Manhunt’
description: Saban Films just secured worldwide distribution rights to the movie shot in Banning and Joshua Tree.

title: How stressed-out plants produce their own aspirin
description: Plants protect themselves from environmental hazards by producing salicylic acid, also known as aspirin. A new understanding of this process may help plants survive climate change.

title: Native American students experience college life during a one-week summer program
description: For 17 years Native American Student Programs has been hosting Gathering of the Tribes, the longest running Native American youth summer program in the UC system.

title: Broccoli gas: a better way to find life in space
description: Broccoli, along with other plants and microorganisms, emit gases to help them expel toxins. Scientists believe these gases could provide compelling evidence of life on other planets.

title: Why the Salton Sea is turning into toxic dust
description: The Salton Sea, California’s most polluted inland lake, has lost a third of its water in the last 25 years. New research has determined a decline in Colorado River flow is the reason for that shrinking.

title: Upward ventilation offers better protection from indoor coronavirus transmission
description: A simple change in the direction of the air forced through indoor gathering spaces by heating, air conditioning, and ventilation systems, could reduce the spread of infectious diseases like COVID-19.

title: 22 Southern California newspapers will be preserved, digitized, and available to the public
description: A John Randolph Haynes and Dora Haynes Foundation grant will help preserve 150 years of local journalism at UC Riverside.

title: Taking photos of slides helps students remember
description: Students often take camera-phone photos of slides during an instructor’s presentation. But the question has lingered whether this practice helps students remember information. A first-of-its-kind study answers the question, finding that taking pictures of PowerPoint slides during an online presentation helped students remember the slide content better than for slides they did not photograph. The study was recently published in the Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition by UC Riverside psychology professor and researcher Annie Ditta.

title: Switching from tobacco to e-cigarettes does not reverse respiratory epithelium damage
description: UC Riverside study reports e-cigarette prolonged use may contribute to airway epithelium damage and lead to respiratory diseases

title: School of Public Policy names its second dean
description: Mark Long has been named dean of UC Riverside’s School of Public Policy effective Jan. 1, 2023. Long is a professor in the Evans School of Public Policy and Governance and an adjunct professor of economics at the University of Washington. He previously served as the Evans School’s associate dean for faculty affairs and associate dean for research.

title: Thirdhand smoke can trigger skin diseases
description: UC Riverside-led clinical study advances molecular understanding of THS effects on skin

title: Join us for UCR’s 2022 Homecoming
description: UC Riverside alumni are invited back to campus for one of the biggest Homecoming celebrations in the university's history. Set for November 18 and 19, the event will celebrate everything UCR — past, present, and future.

title: Discovery could dramatically narrow search for space creatures
description: An Earth-like planet orbiting an M dwarf — the most common type of star in the universe — appears to have no atmosphere at all. This discovery could cause a major shift in the search for life on other planets.

title: Two School of Medicine faculty elected to National Academy of Medicine
description: Deborah Deas and Mario Sims are recognized for their contributions to advancing public health

title: UC Riverside men’s soccer wins first Big West regular season title
description: The UC Riverside Highlanders made history on Saturday evening, downing UC Santa Barbara 4-1 for their first Big West regular season championship in program history. The Highlanders earned the No. 1 seed in the upcoming Big West Men’s Soccer Championship. A ruckus and energetic crowd at UC Riverside Soccer Stadium watched the Highlanders finish job one of two on Saturday.

title: UC Riverside featured in Amazon Prime series
description: UC Riverside's episode on the Amazon Prime streaming series “The College Tour” is now live and viewable on YouTube.

title: Prop 30: A lift for rideshare companies, at the expense of the uber-rich?
description: Proposition 30 would call for Californians earning more than $2 million per year to help fund zero-emission vehicle purchases and infrastructure, and — to a lesser extent — to fund wildfire response and prevention. It would generate between $3.5 to $5 billion annually by taxing the personal incomes of 35,000, or .2% of Californians who account for 30% of the state’s taxable income. Half of the funding dedicated to zero-emissions vehicles, or ZEVs, would go toward rebates for low-to-middle-income residents who buy ZEVs.

title: Remembering Mike Davis, an agent for social change
description: The author and distinguished professor emeritus with UCR’s Department of Creative Writing died on October 25

title: Unwritten history: Seattle, a city built by immigrants and Indigenous people
description: ‘Seattle from the Margins,’ a new book by assistant professor Megan Asaka points to the overseen contributions of the Duwamish, Japanese, Filipino, Chinese, and other immigrant communities.

title: UCR No. 9 among public universities for sustainability
description: UC Riverside is ranked No. 9 among public universities in the Princeton Review’s Guide to Green Colleges. The campus was No. 27 on the overall list of Top 50 Green Colleges, released Oct. 25. The annual list recognizes institutions for superb sustainability practices, strong foundations in sustainability education, and healthy quality of life for students on campus.

title: Apple TV+ series features UCR professor as 'gratitude expert'
description: The lessons in today’s preschool animated series are a moonshot from the anvil-dropping antics of their parents’-parents’ generation. Case in point: UC Riverside psychology researcher Sonja Lyubomirsky is the “gratitude expert” for a new preschool animated series from Apple TV+, “Sago Mini Friends.”

title: Student research gear closet lowers barriers to field experiences
description: Enjoying time in nature is much more comfortable with the right stuff. Gear such as hiking boots and a warm sleeping bag can spell the difference between a transformative experience and an utterly miserable outing. But buying outdoor basics can take considerable financial means. For cash-strapped college students, gear can be a major obstacle to participating in experiences like a biology field trip or a geology club excursion.

title: UCR pundits predict Democrats will take the Senate
description: Most political scientists and prognosticators predict a GOP win in the U.S. House of Representativeson Nov. 8, and so much of the media’s focus has turned to a tighter suite of contests – those for U.S. Senate seats.

title: COVID-19 took serious toll on Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander mental and physical health
description: Two UC Riverside-led studies found concerning psychological and physical health problems among more than 300 NH/PIs in five US states

title: Mexican mangroves have been capturing carbon for 5,000 years
description: Researchers have identified a new reason to protect mangrove forests: they’ve been quietly keeping carbon out of Earth’s atmosphere for the past 5,000 years.

title: A new look at ‘The Chicano Experience’
description: Professor Alfredo Mirandé’s 1985 foundational sociology book has a completely revised second edition.

title: Investing in What Matters
description: Longtime support from philanthropists Mark and Pamela Rubin make a difference in our community and on campus at UCR, changing lives for the better.

title: Chemical cocktail in skin summons disease-spreading mosquitoes
description: A UC Riverside-led team discovered the exact chemical combination that causes Zika, dengue and yellow fever-spreading mosquitoes to locate and land on their victims.

title: Robot sleeves for kids with cerebral palsy
description: UC Riverside engineers are developing low-cost, robotic “clothing” to help children with cerebral palsy gain control over their arm movements.

title: The unintended consequences of using a ventilator
description: Breakthrough research addresses a long-standing question in pulmonary medicine about whether modern ventilators overstretch lung tissue. They do.

title: Massive Mexican earthquakes warn Southern Californians
description: A pair of massive earthquakes in Mexico has some in Southern California on edge, wondering whether the Golden State is next. UC Riverside seismologist Abhijit Ghosh weighs in on the likelihood of more shakers, and how to prepare for them.

title: Latino census data points to college-graduation disparity
description: Sept. 25, the Center for Social Innovation released a report based on census data that asserts only 11% of Latinos in the Inland Empire have a bachelor’s degree or higher, compared with 35% overall in California and 33% nationally. Latinos comprise 51 percent of the 4.65 million people who live in the Inland Empire.

title: Ukraine advances don't equal Russian retreat
description: The past week has been one of alternately hopeful and discouraging news in the 7-months-long invasion of Ukraine by Russia. We asked Ukraine expert Paul D'Anieri for guidance on whether the developments signal a winddown in Russian aggression or if they foretell a next, more perilous chapter. D'Anieri wrote the 2019 book “Ukraine and Russia" and a 2007 book, “Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics and Institutional Design.” For the 2017-18 academic year, he served as a fellow in the Harvard University Ukrainian Research Institution.

title: Inland Empire business activity growth contrasts with national decline
description: Business activity in the Inland Empire continued to rise in the latest numbers, standing in stark contrast to the decline in GDP at the national level, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The increase in the region’s business activity in the second quarter of 2022 (the latest data available) does, however, represent a significant decline in growth from recent quarters.

title: The no-tech way to preserve California’s state grass
description: Though it is disappearing, California’s official state grass has the ability to live for 100 years or more. New research demonstrates that sheep and cattle can help it achieve that longevity.

title: After wildfires, do microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas?
description: Laughing gas is no laughing matter — nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas with 300 times the warming potential of carbon dioxide. Scientists are racing to learn whether microorganisms send more of it into the atmosphere after wildfires.

title: Fall campaigns underway; fans look to basketball openings
description: Schedules are ongoing for many fall sports, with excitement building for the men's and women's basketball seasons, which begin later this fall and come on the heels of impressive 2021-22 campaigns for both. Following are early season reviews and pre-season previews for UC Riverside's fall sports teams.  All ticket purchases for UCR Athletics home events must be made online. Home games are free for UCR students with an R’Card.

title: Liking another group doesn't mean you dislike your own
description: More than 70 years ago, a pair of psychologists conducted a study in which they asked young Black girls to choose between Black and white dolls. The girls overwhelmingly chose white dolls, ascribing positive attributes to them. The Black girls’ choices and reasoning were interpreted by study authors to indicate “a feeling of inferiority among African-American children and damaged... self-esteem.” The die was cast in psychology discourse: If you like a group to which you don’t belong — an “outgroup” — it’s because you have bad feelings about your own group — your “ingroup.”

title: Addressing the anxiety crisis
description: UC Riverside mental health professionals answer questions specific to adults, children, and students

title: Laughing gas in space could mean life
description: Scientists at UC Riverside are suggesting something is missing from the typical roster of chemicals that astrobiologists use to search for life on planets around other stars — laughing gas.

title: 195 ways to help California’s painted ladies
description: By documenting hundreds of new nectar plants for painted ladies, scientists have renewed hope these charismatic butterflies may prove resilient to climate change.

title: Do you act before you think or think before you act?
description: UC Riverside psychologists’ experiments explain which choice rules daily life

title: Fungi and bacteria are binging on burned soil
description: UC Riverside researchers have identified tiny organisms that not only survive but thrive during the first year after a wildfire. The findings could help bring land back to life after fires that are increasing in both size and severity.

title: UCR ARTS: Christina Fernandez’s photo exhibition captures life
description: This is Fernandez’s first major solo museum show. The images reflect on various social issues and explores her Mexican American identity.

title: Coronavirus formation is successfully modeled
description: UC Riverside study could inform the design of effective drugs to fight SARS-CoV-2 and other coronaviruses

title: California will inevitably shake like Turkey
description: Many in California have questions about the conditions that caused the Turkish earthquake, and wonder whether the western U.S. is likely to suffer a similar fate. UC Riverside seismologist David Oglesby weighs in with answers.

title: Upgrading struggle meals with the Cooking Well series
description: If you don’t know what a struggle meal is, we envy your food security.  For the rest of us, perfecting the art of upgrading inexpensive foods so that they’re tastier is a skill many low-on-funds people know too well.

title: University of California Application Filing Period Expanded
description: It was announced on Sept. 30 that prospective students looking to enter the University of California, or UC, system as first-years or transfers can now hit that submit button as early as Sat., Oct. 1.

title: Korean American history to become a traveling exhibition
description: UCR professor receives $850,000 Mellon Foundation grant to share history of American’s first Koreatown.

title: Ghost Light, Marvel’s new cosmic hero, is Black
description: The once human character is now a superhero, envisioned by UCR professor John Jennings.

title: Researcher honored for work in English language learner education
description: The James Irvine Foundation recognized Linda Navarrette as one of six change-makers in California.

title: Primera Generación Dance Collective to perform on Saturday
description: The group, founded by UCR alumni, also brings in UCR, RCC, and A.B. Miller High School dancers. The event is free and open to the public.

title: UCR-led analysis seeks online advertising protocols for data transparency, consumer privacy, and brand safety
description: Several Internet business experts see a technology that has made cryptocurrencies possible as a panacea to today’s online advertising accountability woes that stem from ad-tech giants hoarding the ad engagement data in their walled gardens.

title: Is that a persistent cold, bad allergies, … or long COVID?
description: Dr. Martin Schlusselberg of the UCR School of Medicine explains

title: Grants to assess the needs of California’s Asian American and Pacific Islander populations
description: The AAPI Data program at the University of California, Riverside, announced on Feb. 28 the awarding of $1.1 million in grants to research teams at five University of California campuses to probe the needs of Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders in California, and to provide a set of policy recommendations to address those needs.

title: KD Ganaway exhibition coming to the California Museum of Photography
description: UCR’s California Museum of Photography will showcase the work of King Daniel (KD) Ganaway, one of the earliest Black photographers in the U.S. The exhibition runs Feb. 25 - Aug. 6.

title: Highlanders move into second place after blowout win
description: High-octane offense was on display on both sides at Premier America Credit Union Arena, but UC Riverside proved too much for CSUN on Monday night with a resounding 96-76 win over the Matadors.  Their 19th win, which extended a team record in Division I play, was the Highlanders third straight and vaulted them into sole possession of second place in the hypercompetitive Big West Conference.

title: New Vice Provost & Dean of Undergraduate Education named
description: Louie Rodríguez has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost and dean of undergraduate education (VPDUE), effective April 1.

title: UCR among system leaders in applications increase
description: UC Riverside registered the second largest year-to-year increase in freshmen applications for fall 2023 among University of California campuses, setting a new campus record for applications. Numbers released Friday by the UC system show that overall applications were down 2.2%, while UCR showed a 3.7% increase, with 2,097 additional applicants than during the fall 2022 cycle.

title: Confronting anti-vaccine activism with life-saving narratives
description: Health officials, public policymakers and community leaders should team up to disseminate accurate narratives about the life-saving benefits of vaccines.

title: Retirees Experience Mental and Social Benefits Through Osher Lifelong Learning Institute at UC Riverside
description: Retirees Experience Mental and Social Benefits Through Osher Lifelong Learning Institute at UC Riverside. Donor-supported adult learning program provides local retirees opportunities to build knowledge and develop community.

title: UCR Orchestra honors Black History Month with concerts this weekend
description: Performances also include Pedro Rubio, a Spanish virtuoso clarinetist conducting research at UCR.

title: Does Bing's angsty chatbot foretell the future?
description: Several weeks ago, UCR News published a faculty Q&A about the text-generating capabilities of ChatGPT, and its potential impact on academic essay writing and education. In the ensuing weeks, concerns have been raised about an artificial intelligence-powered chatbot created by OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, that has been incorporated on a test basis in Microsoft’s Bing search engine.

title: Highlanders one win away from Men's Soccer Championship bid
description: The UC Riverside Highlanders will host the Big West Championship final on Saturday against UC Santa Barbara, with the opportunity to win their second conference title in four years.  One more win for the top-seeded Highlanders and they will earn an automatic bid into the 2022 NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship. UCR won its first regular season Big West conference title this year.

title: Highlanders get a cooler, off-campus commencement
description: UC Riverside will hold most of its 2023 Commencement Ceremonies inside the air-conditioned Toyota Arena in Ontario. The new location is less than 20 miles from campus, and UCR Vice Chancellor Brian Haynes said the venue will provide a more well-rounded experience for all attendees.

title: Creating a diverse educational pipeline in microelectronics
description: Scientists at UC Riverside and UC Irvine have received funding of $5 million from the U.S. Department of Energy, or DOE, to team up with Sandia National Laboratory in Albuquerque, New Mexico, in building a diverse educational pipeline in the field of microelectronics — a priority for industry and government. Of this amount, nearly $4 million is allocated to UC Riverside.

title: Breathing is going to get tougher
description: When global temperatures increase by 4 degrees Celsius, harmful plant emissions and dust will also increase by as much as 14 percent, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: Injections for diabetes, cancer could become unnecessary
description: Researchers at UC Riverside are paving the way for diabetes and cancer patients to forget needles and injections, and instead take pills to manage their conditions.

title: The Colorado River is imperiled; why it matters to you
description: UC Riverside experts discuss the decline of this major water source for nearly 40 million people in seven states.

title: 1,700-year-old spider monkey remains discovered in Teotihuacán, Mexico
description: The complete skeletal remains of a spider monkey — seen as an exotic curiosity in pre-Hispanic Mexico — grants researchers new evidence regarding social-political ties between two ancient powerhouses: Teotihuacán and Maya Indigenous rulers.

title: Everyone is invited to UCR Homecoming 2022
description: UC Riverside is celebrating Homecoming 2022 with two days of in-person, on-campus events and there is something to fit everyone’s type of fun.

title: Highlanders men’s soccer starts NCAA Tournament play Thursday
description: The UC Riverside Highlanders, the 2022 Big West regular season and conference tournament champions, will face Portland this Thursday in the first round of the NCAA Men’s Soccer Tournament. The match kicks off at 7 p.m. (Pacific Time) from Merlo Field in Portland and will be broadcast on ESPN+. With a win the Highlanders will move on to face eighth-seeded Oregon State in Corvallis.

title: Author revisits lessons of prison yoga
description: The narrative surrounding the virtues of yoga instruction inside prisons is incomplete, according to a UC Riverside professor who taught yoga in prisons for several years and has written a book about the experience. “There is a false narrative, which is ‘if you improve yourself, you won’t get incarcerated,’” said Farah Godrej, an associate professor of political science. “Inside prisons, this idea of self-improvement is used in a way that’s insidious. It becomes an apparatus for telling incarcerated persons that incarceration is their own fault.”

title: Earth might be experiencing 7th mass extinction, not 6th
description: New research suggests environmental changes caused the first mass extinction event in history, which occurred millions of years earlier than scientists previously realized.

title: Black Friday & Cyber Monday: UCR experts discuss the annual shopping binge ritual
Experts on Black Friday, holiday season shopping impacts
Tiniest Ever Ancient Seawater Pockets Revealed
description: The surprising discovery of seawater sealed in what is now North America for 390 million years opens up a new avenue for understanding how oceans change and adapt with changing climate.

title: Culture war battles at schools harm public education, UC report finds
description: Educators have sought to avoid controversy by pulling back on teaching lessons in civics, politics, and the history and experiences of America’s minority communities.

title: School of Business launches new actuarial science degree program
description: UC Riverside’s School of Business is now offering a degree in actuarial science, providing a direct path for students seeking careers in finance and insurance. Actuarial science is a discipline that involves assessing financial risks using mathematical and statistical methods. Most who study it go on to work in high-paying positions in finance and insurance.

title: Scholarship helps students chart course for science-to-policy careers
description: When six lifelong friends gathered in 2018 for a reunion in California’s Anza-Borrego State Park, they didn’t sit around the campfire telling spooky stories. Instead, they brainstormed ways they could help students at the University of California, Riverside.

title: China response is less visible, not less dangerous
description: In wake of a renewed COVID-19 lockdown, Chinese citizens protested openly in the streets the past several days. It's a rare display in China, where civil unrest is historically greeted with harsh government recriminations. We asked UCR professors Perry Link and Rich Carpiano to weigh in. Link co-translated The Tiananmen Papers, related to the 1989 democracy protests. In response to his role in the translation, since 1996 he has been blacklisted by China.

title: How do worms develop their gut?
description: The pandemic helped a husband-and-wife team at UC Riverside solve the mystery

title: Salton Sea dust triggers lung inflammation
description: UC Riverside study has health implications for people living around California’s largest lake

title: Precise solar observations fed millions in ancient Mexico
description: Without clocks or modern tools, ancient Mexicans watched the sun to maintain a farming calendar that precisely tracked seasons and even adjusted for leap years.

title: Pollution cleanup method destroys toxic “forever chemicals”
description: An insidious category of carcinogenic pollutants known as “forever chemicals” may not be so permanent after all. University of California, Riverside, chemical engineering and environmental scientists recently published new methods to chemically break up these harmful substances found in drinking water into smaller compounds that are essentially harmless.

title: Discovery of antibody structure could lead to treatment for Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus
description: Study provides insights into fighting broad range of pathogen’s viral strains

title: How giant-faced owls snag voles hidden in snow
description: Great gray owls’ physical features, especially parts of their wings and face, help them correct for sonic distortions caused by snow, enabling them to find moving food with astonishing accuracy, according to a new UC Riverside study.

title: Cruising past 'good' and setting their sights on 'great'
description: Coming off its two most successful seasons ever, UC Riverside Men’s Basketball Coach Mike Magpayo said the team was looking to make the jump “from good to great.” The needle is trending toward Magpayo’s goal. Following a win against Idaho on Dec. 11, the men’s team has won five of its last six games. And his players are hot, having captured Big West Player of the Week honors for two of the past three weeks.

title: Making Connections and Sharing Histories
description: Distinguished Professor Clifford Trafzer reflects on 15 years as the Rupert Costo Chair in American Indian Affairs, the world’s first American Indian chair endowment.

title: UCR expert: President Biden’s new same-sex marriage law ‘is a reminder that a right won is not a right secured’
description: The Respect for Marriage Act ‘seems to be an evolution on same-sex marriage support. But I want to caution that we don’t conflate that with LGBTQ support.’

title: Business activity in the Inland Empire is still on the rise and expected to continue growing in 2023
description: Business activity in the Inland Empire has continued to rise and despite the turbulence in today’s macroeconomy, is forecast to continue its upward climb in the near-term future.

title: Are you voting for a populist candidate?
description: Study highlights potential for populist leaders to undermine democracy.

title: Post-lockdown auto emissions can’t hide in the grass
description: University of California scientists have a new way to demonstrate which neighborhoods are most affected by air pollution from vehicle emissions. Their technique could help ensure people most affected by pollution will benefit from efforts to reduce it.

title: Skip the angry-letter-never-sent; try a grateful one
description: It’s long been said that writing an angry letter – but not mailing it —– is an effective way of venting without backlash. UC Riverside researchers say the converse — penning letters-never-sent expressing gratitude — carries a benefit, as well. There is an entire area of study in psychology devoted to gratitude, including its benefits and how to practice it. Gratitude, in terms of psychology research, is the acknowledgment of a kindness or benefit from another person. Research has identified expressing gratitude as one of the most successful happiness strategies.

title: Is Swift retribution in the offing for Ticketmaster?
description: A chaotic rollout of tickets for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour has drawn renewed scrutiny of whether Ticketmaster unfairly dominates the ticketing industry, a charge that first surfaced in earnest in a 1990s skirmish with the grunge band Pearl Jam. We asked UCR experts whether Ticketmaster is a monopoly and should be subjected to antitrust action.

title: UCR's founding School of Public Policy dean to step down after a groundbreaking run
description: As Anil Deolalikar prepared to step down this week as the founding dean of UCR’s School of Public Policy, he reflected on a groundbreaking career marked by repeatedly choosing a more challenging path. Consider when he completed his Bachelor of Arts degree in economics at Harvard University in 1977 with summa cum laude honors. The world was at his palm, but the obvious option of going to a top business or law school “never really crossed my mind,” he said.  “A lot of my friends were going into business, law, and medicine, and so they thought I was a little crazy,” he said.

title: 'Rockonomics' professor: Ticketmaster gets a bad rap
description: A chaotic rollout of tickets for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour has drawn renewed scrutiny of whether Ticketmaster unfairly dominates the ticketing industry. We asked Carolyn Sloane, a UC Riverside economics professor, whether Ticketmaster has outsized influence on ticket prices. Sloane teaches a "Rockonomics" course and is a "Swiftie" — a Taylor Swift fan. Follow this link for a related Q&A with antitrust expert Ken MacVey.

title: Elon Musk: An 'arbitrary' town hall moderator
description: In October, Elon Musk took control of Twitter in a $44 billion deal, saying he hoped to enhance Twitter’s mission as “a digital town square." His changes to moderation practices have since led civil rights groups to allege his actions will increase hate speech and misinformation. This week, Musk’s Twitter raised alarms by suspending several high-profile journalists, drawing the condemnation of entities including The United Nations, the European Union, and the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Decoding the secret language of photosynthesis
description: For decades, scientists have been stumped by the signals plants send themselves to initiate photosynthesis, the process of turning sunlight into sugars. UC Riverside researchers have now decoded those previously opaque signals.

title: Winter break activities for on the go … or on the couch
description: Whether you plan to stay indoors or enjoy the outdoors, check out this list of ideas from UCR staff.

title: Pandemic left behind, the Inland Empire economy flourished in 2022
description: Despite the recession drumbeat getting louder in many quarters across the nation, the Inland Empire’s economy is not only showing strength, but is outstripping California’s other major metros and the state as a whole along some very key measures, according to an analysis released today by the UC Riverside School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

title: Writers Week honors authors Percival Everett and Mike Davis
description: The 46th annual UC Riverside event is scheduled for Feb. 13-17. Writers Week is free and open to the public.

title: Culturally-informed mental health screenings improve student, school and community successes
description: As concerns about youth mental health, school shootings, and other forms of violence prompt more school systems to conduct mental health screenings, a UC Riverside-led analysis is urging school officials to proceed with deference to student family, cultural, and community backgrounds.

title: Studies identify new strategies for insect control
description: Mosquitoes spread several diseases, such as malaria and dengue. In 2020 about 241 million cases of malaria occurred worldwide, with a few more million cases occurring in 2021.

title: Turning plastic waste into a valuable soil additive
description: University of California, Riverside, scientists have moved a step closer to finding a use for the hundreds of millions of tons of plastic waste produced every year that often winds up clogging streams and rivers and polluting our oceans.

title: Music and ayahuasca’s role in treating substance use disorders in men
description: UC Riverside researcher finds the crucial role icaros, traditional Peruvian songs, play during ayahuasca healing ceremonies.

title: Who'll stop the rain? California's got nowhere to put it
description: After several weeks of rain, Southern California remains under advisories for flooding, high winds, and high surf. Early this week, 90% of California was under a flood watch. L.A. County — which has received 2 to 6 inches of rain along the coast and in coastal valleys and about 8 inches in the mountains — could see an additional .5 to 1.5 inches, with more expected at higher elevations, meteorologists say.

title: Landscaping for drought: we’re doing it wrong
description: Many Southern Californians plant trees prized for drought tolerance, but a new UC Riverside-led study shows that these trees lose this tolerance once they’re watered.

title: Kid Kongo Powers: Post-punk, culture, and identity
description: Richard T. Rodríguez, UC Riverside professor of English and media and cultural studies, will host a joint reading and conversation with Kid Congo Powers, an author and musician widely known for being part of bands such as The Gun Club, The Cramps, and Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, as well as for leading his own group, The Pink Monkey Birds.

title: Highlanders fend off Cal Poly, move into first place in Big West
description: UC Riverside welcomed students back to campus on Monday at a packed SRC Arena, treating them to free extra basketball with a thrilling 83-78 overtime win over Cal Poly to move into first place in the Big West. The Highlanders are now 6-1 in conference play, the best start in program history.  Monday's win was the seventh straight in the series for UCR, the Highlanders' longest current winning streak over any conference opponent.

title: Gas stoves: Suddenly, the pariah du jour
description: One-third of U.S. households — more than 40 million homes — cook with gas.

title: Prof pours cold water on coffee pod controversy
description: New research from the University of Quebec declares coffee pods are “better for the planet than filtered brew.” Here to weigh in on the matter is UCR's Andrew Gray, who studies the movement of plastic pollutants through the environment.

title: Is ChatGPT a threat to education?
description: UC Riverside experts share thoughts on the AI-powered language model that understands and responds to natural language

title: Asian American shootings: This is ‘not an exception’ and other issues that need to be discussed
description: Farm working, mental health, and social and cultural barriers that some Asian American communities face.

title: Gun violence pressures elected officials to make reforms
description: With three mass shooting within a week leaving 24 Californians dead, public policy makers are searching for answers.

title: Health impact of chemicals in plastics is handed down two generations
description: UC Riverside mouse study finds paternal exposure to phthalates increases risk of metabolic diseases in progeny

title: Athletics releases spring schedules
description: UC Riverside’s Department of Intercollegiate Athletics this week released schedules for its spring athletic teams.  Baseball  UC Riverside head baseball coach Justin Johnson has announced the Highlanders’ 2023 schedule. UC Riverside returns more than half of its starting lineup from 2022 and its top three starting pitchers in Tyler Frazier, Tucker Juline, and Eric Marrujo. Click here for the full schedule.

title: Soil tainted by air pollution expels carbon
description: New UC Riverside research suggests nitrogen released by gas-powered machines causes dry soil to let go of carbon and release it back into the atmosphere, where it can contribute to climate change.

title: COVID-19 lockdowns reduced disease spread but with costs
description: The lockdowns at the beginning of COVID-19 pandemic reduced the spread of infection by an estimated 56%, a recent study has found. If all governors did not issue any lockdowns until April 23, 2020, the number of cases would have been five times higher by April 30, 2020, the study asserts. But the lockdowns came with economic costs.

title: The planet that could end life on Earth
description: A terrestrial planet hovering between Mars and Jupiter would be able to push Earth out of the solar system and wipe out life on this planet, according to a UC Riverside experiment.

title: Study examines straight men and their sexual attraction to transgender women
description: An analysis of online Reddit conversations also revealed a paradox: the same men devalue both trans and cisgender women.

title: A Highlander DREAMer's dilemma
description: Gabriela Martinez is nervous about her trip to Washington D.C. Not because she’s going to be in the same building as the President of the United States. Nah, it isn't that. She’s nervous because this trip to the 2023 State of the Union, or SOTU, is the same week as her econ midterm.

title: Black stories, culture, and Hollywood
description: In this Q&A UCR experts discuss culture, history, and the importance of Black films.

title: UCR professor launches Emotion and Society Lab
description: New lab is a multi-disciplinary effort that involves faculty from around the world.

title: California study finds that growing political conflict hinders learning and increases hostility
description: A new analysis by researchers at UC Riverside and UCLA shows that even in blue state California, political attacks on public schools are pervasive and growing, hindering learning and the role schools play in a diverse democracy.  Political division and community-level conflict is negatively impacting student interactions, and many California students are experiencing hostility and intolerance in school. Troublingly, the research finds high levels of hostile comments toward LGBTQ students, and racist remarks targeting Latino, and in particular, African American students.

title: California Museum of Photography turns 50
description: The California Museum of Photography has been documenting history, art, and community for 50 years. Its collection of cameras, photographs, and art will be on display at “CMP at 50,” a five-month celebration that kicks off Saturday, March 18, 2023. The anniversary reception is set for April 15, 6 p.m. It is free and open to the public.

title: UCR environmental engineers to referee California’s big rig truck emission regulation
description: They won’t be wearing vivid black and white striped shirts, but they could. University of California, Riverside, environmental engineers will soon serve as referees in California’s drive for big rig trucks to meet the state’s tailpipe emission standards.

title: UCR report explores consequences of high cost housing in the Inland Empire
description: A report released by the University of California, Riverside, probes Inland Southern California's high rates for cost-burdened households and details the consequences.  Entitled “Housing and Sustainability in the Inland Region: Affordability, Equity, and Changing Demographics,” the report cites research that found 41.5% of the households in the region are cost-burdened, in which residents spend nearly a third or more of their incomes on housing.

title: Capturing heavier rains in an era of drought
description: UC Riverside public policy professor Kurt Schwabe was just awarded a Fulbright Distinguished Chair Fellowship to collaborate with Australian scientists to better capture and store runoff water as the planet warms.

title: Humans bite back by deactivating mosquito sperm
description: New UC Riverside research makes it likely that proteins responsible for activating mosquito sperm can be shut down, preventing them from swimming to or fertilizing eggs.

title: Why the NBA is seeking technology built by UCR students and alumni
description: EDGE Sound Research, co-founded by a student and an alum, was one of seven companies from around the world selected for the NBA Launchpad program.

title: Hunting Venus 2.0: Scientists sharpen their sights
description: With the first paper compiling all known information about planets like Venus beyond our solar system, scientists are the closest they’ve ever been to finding an analog of Earth’s “twin.”

title: Without this, plants cannot respond to temperature
description: UC Riverside scientists have significantly advanced the race to control plant responses to temperature on a rapidly warming planet. Key to this breakthrough is miRNA, a molecule nearly 200,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair.

title: UC Riverside is No. 1 for retaining Pell Grant freshmen
description: A report from The Chronicle of Higher Education gives UC Riverside a No. 1 ranking in freshmen retention rates. UCR is ranked alongside 24 other campuses nationwide that lead the charge in serving low-income students.

title: Women on corporate boards increase company buyout value
description: The presence of women board members increased the value of companies targeted for acquisition by as much as 5%, study found.

title: Even Sonoran Desert plants aren’t immune to climate change
description: In North America’s hottest, driest desert, climate change is causing the decline of plants once thought nearly immortal and replacing them with shorter shrubs that can take advantage of sporadic rainfall and warmer temperatures.

title: Surprise effect: Methane cools even as it heats
description: Most climate models do not yet account for a new UC Riverside discovery: methane traps a great deal of heat in Earth’s atmosphere, but also creates cooling clouds that offset 30% of the heat.

title: UC Riverside gets $3.8 million grant to support student-parents
description: UC Riverside’s Early Childhood Services, or ECS, and Women’s Resource Center, or WRC, have received a $3.8 million grant through the Child Care Access Means Parents in School Program, or CCAMPIS. The grant is offered by the U.S.

title: Celebrity sightings have a built-in contradiction
description: UC Riverside research helps explain a tradeoff in human behavior

title: LA Times executive editor is Hays Lecture Series speaker
description: Kevin Merida, executive editor of the Los Angeles Times, will be the speaker at the 54th Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture at UC Riverside. The May 9 lecture will be in person, on campus for the first time in three years. Merida, 66, took the helm of the largest newsgathering organization in the West in June 2021 and oversees the Times newsroom, as well as Times Community News and Los Angeles Times en Español.

title: One of every six autistic children are expelled from daycare
description: University of California, Riverside, study found that 16% of autistic children of surveyed parents were expelled from daycares resulting in more problems for them in elementary school.

title: Head men’s basketball coach Mike Magpayo signs 5-year contract extension
description: UC Riverside head men’s basketball coach and 2022-23 Big West Coach of the Year, Mike Magpayo, has signed a new five-year deal that will keep him at the helm of the Highlanders’ program through the 2027-28 season. Magpayo’s new contract comes on the heels of UCR’s best season in the program’s Division I history.

title: One year later: Surprises, disappointments in Ukraine war
description: This is a partial reprint from a UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation, or IGCC, retrospective on Russia's war in Ukraine. The retrospective featured UC Riverside faculty members Paul D'Anieri and Jana Grittersova, among other experts from the UC system.

title: How an autism gene contributes to infertility
description: UC Riverside mouse study shows how gene mutation leads to ovaries failing prematurely

title: UC Riverside-led study sheds light on how IBD can develop
description: Inflammatory bowel disease, or IBD, describes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, two chronic diseases that cause inflammation in the intestines. IBD, which affects about 3 million adults in the United States, is an autoimmune disorder — a condition in which the body’s immune system attacks healthy tissues. Its symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, fatigue, weight loss, and stomach cramps.

title: Inland Empire stem-cell therapy gets $2.9 million booster
description: A new UC Riverside training program will help undergraduates transition into regenerative medicine careers, infusing the Inland Empire with expertise in cutting-edge trauma and disease treatments.

title: Manganese in Central Valley water threatens fetuses and children
description: Water in California’s Central Valley contains enough manganese to cause cognitive disabilities and motor control issues in children, and Parkinson’s-like symptoms in adults.

title: From drought to deluge: What’s next for California?
description: UCR faculty expert on municipal water helps readers make sense of seemingly conflicting headlines about California's drought status and water supplies.

title: Free concert launches Dean’s Speaker Series at UC Riverside
description: Among other events, the series features Simon Tam, an author, musician, and activist who won a landmark Supreme Court case in 2017.

title: Researchers warn of tick-borne disease babesiosis
description: UC Riverside and Yale University team sequences and mines genome of the pathogen Babesia duncani

title: Most Californians are getting a tax deadline extension
description: For most Californians, this year’s tax season is a procrastinator’s dream come true.

title: Poverty is the 4th greatest cause of U.S. deaths
description: David Brady

title: Methane from megafires: more spew than we knew
description: Using a new detection method, UC Riverside scientists found a massive amount of methane, a super-potent greenhouse gas, coming from wildfires — a source not currently being accounted for by state air quality managers.

title: Not such small things: microplastics in our streams
